{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3127810,"name":"Anish","username":"REALDEAL123","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/realdeal123/{size}/181947_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-17T01:10:32.253Z","cooked":"

This is my first post, so forgive me if I messed it up.

The question I asked above and also how reliably were they able to get a 5 ball auto working? I was able it get it to work, but it was very unreliable partly due to the odometry.

also, if you have any suggestions on how to make it more reliable, I would love to hear it. Here is the code: GitHub - IronRiders/RapidReact-Commad-Based at Anish-AutoPaths-Testing

Look to FTC for reliable odometry for mecanum. There is much more time used iterating for that.
A really solid mecanum auto for FTC was shown here. It’s one of the best in the world.

Typing in FTC Odometry into youtube resulted in a varied of different results. Take a look at some of those and then come back and ask any further questions you might have!

UnofficialForth:

A really solid mecanum auto for FTC was shown here . It’s one of the best in the world.

Gluten Free used a variation on pure pursuit for mecanum drives. Most teams these days use RoadRunner, which provides similar approaches to WPILib’s path planning.

Many FTC teams do not use drivetrain encoders to do mecanum localization opting instead for passive omni deadwheel rollers.

image694×540 61 KB

Due to Rev firmware quirks many run odometry using three of these but in FRC you have better options and can do with 2 rollers + IMU.)

The most prominent use of mecanum for autonomous in FRC is likely 1986 2017 who used it to run a short path and hit >40 kpa in the first 15 seconds, and almost won Championships for their efforts.

You can definitely make mecanum routines very consistent with software and hardware work, but it’s going to be a lot of work doing something not a lot of other FRC teams do when you can just do swerve instead.

The Blue Alliance

Martians - Team 494 (2022)

FIRST Robotics Competition team from Goodrich, Michigan, USA.

The Blue Alliance

Semis 2 Match 1 - 2022 FIRST in Michigan State Championship - Consumers...

Semis 2 Match 1 at the 2022 FIRST in Michigan State Championship - Consumers Energy Division FIRST Robotics Competition in University Center, MI, USA.

494 Martians was mecanum and ran a 5 ball auto at Michigan state championship, and were rank 2 division finalists.
